coredata.dc:title: Contribution of inner-sphere reorganization in electron-transfer reaction in solution
coredata.dc:creator: Khan, Shahed U.M.
O'M. Bockris, John
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A recently published paper in which the inner- and outer-sphere contributions in redox reactions are compared is incorrect. If one uses the experimental values for the force constants, rather than those calculated from the Urey—Bradley method, one finds R inner = 1.6 R out, where R represents the reorganization energy.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 99, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 July 1983 COMMENT CONTRIBUTION OF INNER-SPHERE REORGANIZATION IN ELECTRON-TRANSFER REACTION IN SOLUTION Shahed U.M. KHAN and John O'M. BOCKRIS Department of Chemistry, Texas A&MUniversity. College Station. Texas 77843, USA Received 19 March 1983; in final fonn 19 May 1983 A recently published paper in which the inner- and outer-sphere contributions in redox reactions are compared is incor- rect- If one uses the experimental values for the force constants, rather than those calculated from the Urey Bradley meth- od, one finds -Rinner = 1-6-^out*"^11210^ represents the reorganization energy - Recently, the free energy of reorganization for the electron-transfer reaction in solution has been deter- mined using a photoemission experiment [1]- In a sub- sequent analysis it was reported [2] that the contribu- tion of outer-sphere reorganization, JS^^, is markedly larger than that of inner-sphere, -Kinner- ^n this article we reanalyze the experimental results [1,2] of the free energy of reorganization and show that an error in the origin of the inner-sphere reorganization energy calcula- tion has led to the published result [2] which should indeed be inverted. The contribution of inner-sphere reorganization cal- culated earlier was made on the basis of computations due to Hale [3] who used force constants obtained by the Urey Bradley method [4]. Thus, in this method, the total forces acting on the ion solvent bond arising from the stretching and the interaction between the neighboring non-bonding atoms are resolved into two force constants, one of which is taken as the stretching force constant. This resolved one (only) was used by Hale [3]. One should, in fact, use the experimental force constants corresponding to the symmetric stretch- ing frequency [5 7]. From photoemission experiments [1] the reorgani- zation energy, R^(expt), has been found by means of calculations via a Born Haber cycle for reactions of the type M^aq) A^ M^aq) + e(gas). (1) If one accepts that this energy is a combination of ^(expt)=/?^+^Jcalc) (2) one can obtain R^ from the values of-R^Cexpt), by substituting for22,,mm.(calc) from the theoretical ex- pression of free energy of activation AG^ng,(calc) (for one reactant ion) [5 7], ^inner^) inner -L^-Jo'-'I -1 "~~' /-,.. where n is the number of water or ligand molecules oriented orthogonally to an ion in the first shell when the ion is in solution, / and/,, are respectively the force constant for the ion solvent vibration in the oxidized and reduced ion, and Z^ is the equilibrium ion solvent bond length difference of the oxidized and reduced ion. However, for the exchange reactions involving two reactant ions the corresponding inner-sphere reorganiza- tion energy .Rfnn^^calc) can be expressed using eq. No correlation is found between R ^"""s0.0 and ./^^""^(calc). The photoemission experiments are, therefore, inconsistent witli the model upon which eq. (6) is based. Earlier [2] a comparison was made between ^change, 6 ^^ with ^"^(calc) [=^.^(calc> This is, however, an incorrect comparison since for an electrode reaction the outer-sphere reorganization en- ergy,^?^110'36, becomes about half of ^y^ due to presence of image forces near the electrode [7]. A comparison between ./^^"'^(calc) and ^o^11"'"1^'0 is nlade in table \ I1 is seen that the use of experimental force constants [8,10] inverts the conclu- sion given earlier [2], which was that^^^Ccalc)/ R'^aag.e.D < i Jn fact, using the experimental force constants [8,10], the average value of.R^^'^calc)/ ^oS1""18'5'0 = 1-6 (fron1 column 6 of table 1), so that the conclusion of the earlier paper [2] should be in- verted. The following remarks can be made about the Reply [11]: (i) It is not correct that the interpretations in our Comment are the same as those in the recent paper [2]. 84 Volume 99, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 July 1983 Table I Relative contributions of inner-sphere and outer-sphere reorganization energy Reactants ^n^P^ ^hange^b) ^exchange.D ^gxchange^) ^""^(calc) (eV)^ using expt. force = column 2 from Marcus' constants ^column 3 expression Dexchange.D out (eV) (eV) (eV)<=) v^/v3-- 2.13 2.08 1.1 1.14 1.89 Cr^/Cr3* 2.05 2.2 0.95 1-14 2-32 Mn^/Mn3* 2.02 1.84 1.1 1.12 1.67 Fe^/Fe3* 2-11 1.44 1.39 1-14 1.04 Co^/Co^ 2.26 1.64 1.44 1.14 1.14 a) From ref. [2],R^=R^R-^(c^). 0) From eqs. (3), (4) and (6) using n = 6 (cfrefs. [8,9]). c) From eq. (7). That paper [2] interpreted the dominant contribution of outer-sphere reorganization, -Router' ^ut we showed that it is the inner sphere which is dominant for the ex- perimental data used by Delahay [2]. Thus the interpre- tation involves a reversal. (ii) The author of ref. [2] contradicts his experimen- tal data [1] by mentioning in his Reply [11] that it is pointless to argue that inner-sphere reorganization en- ergies are dominant, which one, in fact, gets from his data [1] when proper experimental force constants and correct comparisons are used. (iii) In table 1 of the Reply [II], the systems are different from those we have used. The values of re- organization energies for these different systems are obtained from the values of rate constants [12] with the assumption that sucli reactions are adiabatic in na- ture though, in fact, there is indication to the contrary [13]. Hence, data of different origins should not be utilized to compare the interpretations of data obtained from photoemission experiments [ 1 ] that involved no assumption of adiabaticity. (iv) The systems mentioned in table 1 of the Reply [11] are exceptional [12,14]. Some values were taken from the ions of similar structure. d^ Quantities in parentheses are obtained using Aq value from EXAFS data [12]. 85 Volume 99, number : CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 July 1983 ticity correction of 10~3 would make then activation- less processes- (v) We used the conventional method of computing the reduced mass, 11. to calculate the force constants. However, the use of the mass of the water molecule as the 11 in the aqua complexes supports our conclusion even more, showing an average ratio of.r?,nner/^outer= 3.2 (table 2) compared to 1.6 obtained earlier (table 1). (vi) The use of the more recent values of the differ- ences of metal ligand distances, &q, from EXAFS data (which exists for three out of five of the com- plexes in table 2), increases the contribution of/?;nner so that the average ratio ofP^^/Ry^i = 4-2 (table 2)- We gratefully acknowledge the support of this work by tlie Robert A. head.ce:title: Contribution of inner-sphere reorganization in electron-transfer reaction in solution

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas 77843, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A recently published paper in which the inner- and outer-sphere contributions in redox reactions are compared is incorrect. If one uses the experimental values for the force constants, rather than those calculated from the Urey—Bradley method, one finds R inner = 1.6 R out, where R represents the reorganization energy.
